author: JannikEmmerich
body:
# Summary of the new feature/enhancement
If you use git bash, you can use auto-complete to complete subcommands as shown in the screenshot.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22866859/80716668-38f00d00-8af8-11ea-9dc1-ef633bdca032.png)

This is not possible in the PowerShell, instead the auto-complete suggests the folders in the current directory.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I guess @rjmholt has great news for your.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
For Git specifically, checkout `posh-git` https://github.com/dahlbyk/posh-git Not only does it provide command completion for Git, it also shows a repo's Git status in the prompt text.
GitHub
dahlbyk/posh-git
A PowerShell environment for Git. Contribute to dahlbyk/posh-git development by creating an account on GitHub.

comments.author: JannikEmmerich
comments.body:
@rkeithhill works fine for Git! 
But it would be nice to have such a feature for every subcommand in PowerShell.

comments.author: jcotton42
comments.body:
Native command completion comes down to people having written completers. PowerShell is able to do that automatically for cmdlets and functions because it has all the necessary metadata, but this not true for native (i.e. external to PowerShell) commands.
`posh-git` just so happens to register a completer for `git` when you import it.
